reviewText: For a happy, feel good movie with lots of layers, intrigue, comedy, romance, hot actors, great acting, and a surprise twist don't miss this film! I am so sorry to see it get lambasted by more professional reviewers in newspapers because this movie was wonderful. It was fun and lacked any of the stupid gross body humor found in a lot of (suspense) romantic comedies these days.

Tom Cruise and Charlize Theron were the original leads, thank God this did not happen. I have not seen a movie that I've loved in a long time. Romance, mystery, humor, and class are the foundation of this breath taking cinema. I wish all movies could be this spectacular!

Most likely this movie will work for true fans of film from the 1950's and 1960's.  The Tourist harkens back to a time when stories were presented as a sophisticated genre.  What?  No instant answers?  No blood and flames and explosions?  You have to be engaged with not only the senses but also the brain to fully enjoy this hat tip to an earlier era of film-making.

To set some information straight about the characters, Jolie's character is named Elise - not Elsie.  Depp plays his role of bumbling traveler to a T and Rufus Sewell adds a thread of mystery that has you guessing.

If you haven't watched many foreign or Hitchcock suspense films set in the jet-set locals of Europe or been enamored by the slow pace of The Day of the Jackal, then you may find this film out of synch with your typical expectations.  This film is rich with scenery, fashion, wealth, and low key twisty intrigue.  What it lacks compared to today's heavy handedness of a Borne Identity type film is exactly what makes this refreshing.  The cinematography is stellar.

The best:  Lush backgrounds and lean, well dressed characters with a higher level of vocabulary than the typical language du jour of most recent films.  The worst:  Probably too slow paced for the run of the mill viewer.  The in-between:  Drop the expectations of a Hollywood cookie cutter film adrenaline high and be entertained by the locale, the language, and the intrigue.

This is worth seeing if you are a serious film buff.

In "The Tourist," director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck does his best to recreate the great suspense films of the late 50s. Think Technicolor Hitchcock starring Cary Grant in "North By Northwest" or "To Catch a Thief" where the locale becomes a character and the plot relies on the whimsy and romantic persona of the lead male actor and his seemingly magnetic talent to attract primo women. Perhaps, von Donnersmarck feels that Johnny Depp with his quirky ability to masquerade as a multitude of oddball personalities (Captain Jack Sparrow of the Pirates of the Caribbean Collection franchise, Dean Corso in The Ninth Gate and more recently The Mad Hatter in Alice in Wonderland) can emulate the insouciance and nerdy nonchalance of Roger Thornhill and John Robie, both Cary Grant creations. If, additionally and in the same sense, Angelina Jolie can totter in the 4 inch heels of the mysterious fashionistas Grace Kelly and Eva Marie Saint with their knowing ability to manipulate their men and conquer their worlds effortlessly, the film would come together as both a homage and modern take on the classic thriller where through the error of mistaken identity, an average innocent person is hurtled into a life threatening situation that inevitably rocks his world romantically for the better. "The Tourist" has all the right ingredients, but manages to fall short with perhaps too much editing and not enough background story. The chemistry between the leads is meant to sizzle and relay to the audience just why one does anything for love. However, some of the motivating factors are never spelled out or revealed with any anticipation or impact. Sadly, the result seems a waste of talent and a film that doesn't intelligently scintillate as its advertising promises. In this case, Depp plays the innocent being led into the slaughter by femme fatale Jolie. As with the Hitchcockian leads, their universe of espionage sparkles with the beauty of exotic locale--"Tourist" amply utilizes the Renaissance splendor of the Doge's Venice, scenes of luxurious hotels, glittering ballrooms and enchanted waterways as well as the elegant bustle of Paris where old world meets new at the immense Gare de Lyon for another classic innuendo-filled interlude on the TGV. Grant and Kelly in a coupe on Monaco's famous hairpin turns are swapped for Depp and Jolie en water taxis traversing the canals of La Serenissima. They all clean up nicely, donning tuxedos and gowns for the obligatory ballroom scene where the innocent has his "ah-ha" moment and accepts his new heroic role, cleverly driving the plot to its climatic scene and satisfying aftermath. Perhaps, director von Donnersmarck, feels that like the audiences of the 50s and early 60s, audiences today, tired of the austerity ensuing from financial insecurity, wish to return to an escapist genre of beautiful films featuring extravagantly dressed women and men with money to burn and an almost derogative nonchalance regarding its worth. If this is so, to pull it all off more tightly, where the glitz of his locale and his two stars accent the story to perfection, he has a few things to reconsider. His leads must balance their elegance with a humanness that the audience feels and applauds. Jolie is beautiful--her slim body draped in spectacular clothes that cause men and women both to stare unabashedly as she passes by like a reigning queen may seem a little overdone, but not completely unreasonable. She is, after all, Angelina Jolie--so, why wouldn't we look? As Elise, she doesn't speak much--just looks confidant, slinking through Paris and Venice, knowing full well wherever she goes she will be well received. And, why not? Nonetheless, despite this obvious perfection, when she taunts Depp with luminous eyes that suggest her struggle between the allegiance of career and the overwhelming tour de force that is love, she seems overly controlled--more a study of a woman in love rather than the actual being. Jolie's performance aptly illustrates the difficulty to convey the rush associated with love and the ability to remain coolly elegant. Depp can be mischievously attractive--but Cary Grant he is not. Jack Sparrow, yes. But, he has his moments where the audience laughs out loud. His jaunt across the Venice rooftops (again in homage to "To Catch a Thief") emulates Jack Sparrow slowly and comically sinking in his dinghy when we first lay eyes on him in the first of the Pirates of the Caribbean films. However, in "Tourist" this farce of Depp in his PJs running for his life confuses rather than amuses. Nonetheless, Depp as the archetypical Scamp charms us effortlessly; it is always a pleasure watching a good-looking man with a self-deprecating attitude win while in a situation with the odds stacked against him. Depp doesn't have his usual crazy range to fall back on; he seems to be holding back--trying for restraint to not give too much away and unfortunately loosing too much of the whacky persona the audience wishes most to see. The secondary characters work better. Paul Bettany and Timothy Dalton are both delicious as Scotland yard personnel. They blunder well while impeccably dressed, but other than the fact that as police on a case, the audience is not privy to the almost manic drive of Bettany to get his man. The relationship between Bettany and his superior Dalton calls to mind Clousseau and Chief Inspector Dreyfus--even though "Tourist" thinks of itself as a different type of film when compared to Blake Edward's The Pink Panther Film Collection (The Pink Panther / A Shot in the Dark / Strikes Again / Revenge of / Trail of) series. But perhaps that is where Tourist fails. Maybe it should be whackier. Maybe Depp should have been allowed to channel a different type of innocent--one with Jack Sparrow's ruthless sense of humor and unconventional mores. The hybrid nature of "Tourist" bewilders the audience into thinking something more is on its way that never quite arrives once the plot settles into the familiar ground that Hitchcock does way better. From the Hitchcockian standpoint, the storyline of "Tourist" may be a little weak with not enough moments between Jolie and Depp to make their more profound attraction more believable. Think Eva Marie Saint, Cary Grant and that tunnel in North by Northwest. Whoa what a ride! Eva is on a mission, but she cannot help but be charmed. In her attempt to be `the mystery woman,' Jolie seems to struggle a bit--trying too hard to be imperturbable, the audience does not always see her vulnerability and it wants to feel the chemistry. In this regard, the interlude on the train should have been more provocative, perhaps with some flashbacks to the Jolie character's affair with the infamous Alexander Pierce to show her confusion over her attraction to Depp and the allegiance she still feels for her lover. The city of Venice anoints the film with the benediction of its scintillating beauty and director of photographer, John Seale, can hardly ask for a better backdrop or assignment. However, the city itself has mysteries of its own that could have been integrated into the story to make going to Venice less of a advertised travelogue and more the final destination culminating not only the Scotland Yard investigation, but the affair of the heart. Somehow with more thought to the film's genre identity, as well as to the various factions of the story, the whole film would have benefited as a more adroitly crafted entertainment. Bottom line? "The Tourist" attempts to recreate the mood of the late 50s Hitchcockian thriller/romance with two attractive leads whose chemistry drives the action. At the same time, some whacky moments intervene that suggest a tug towards the crazy comedy of the Pink Panther series. Because this film does not know which genre it is trying to emulate, it fails on both levels. Depp and Jolie try to pull it off by being beautiful people in the wondrous setting of Venice. However, every once and a while, this reviewer wanted to see Depp in a madman's disguise--with that incredible braid in his beard and that twinkle in his eye. Along those same lines, Beauty, as personified by Jolie, requires some chink in the amour of perfection--less polished tones and more passionate screaming. Recommended nevertheless for its abundant display of the glories of Venice. Diana Faillace Von Behren "reneofc"

Angelina Jolie's appearance in "The Tourist" may someday set records for sheer photogenic appeal. She plays one of the most glamorous undercover agents ever to grace the silver screen; her wardrobe, her makeup, and her hair are all immaculate, and for some strange reason, they stay that way all 103 minutes of the film. Even when her character is roughed up by an odious mobster near the end, she still looks as if she has been prepped for a "Vanity Fair" photo shoot. This is, of course, a testament to her beauty as well as to the capable hands of her makeup artists, her hairdressers, and costume designer Colleen Atwood. Credit also to co-writer/director Florian Henkel von Donnersmarck for letting the camera linger on her face and figure a little longer than necessary. He clearly knew what the people wanted to see.

But where does that leave the film itself? Is it supposed to be less about plot and more about serving as an extended fashion show? This is one of the few action thrillers that doesn't get away with being preposterous, for it doesn't have the conviction to go all out with it. Unlike Jolie's previous action film, "Salt," "The Tourist" is timid and flimsy. The stunts are never daring enough, the romance isn't passionate enough, and the sense of humor is so reserved that it seems completely out of place. The story is exceedingly simple, pretty much to the point that it barely holds our interest. Worst of all is the lack of onscreen chemistry between Jolie and costar Johnny Depp. The only real credit I can give it is for its beautiful cinematography and breathtaking scenery, the canals and Byzantine architecture of Venice shot with the same care and precision of an Italian tourism commercial.

In the film, Jolie plays Elsie Clifton-Ward, a British beauty who cunningly misleads a federal investigation of her former lover, the unseen Alexander Pearce, a career criminal wanted in many countries by many people. This includes the heatless gangster Reginald Shaw (Steve Berkoff), who he embezzled billions from. Scotland Yard's Inspector John Acheson (Paul Bettany) has been keeping tabs on Elsie for two years in the desperate hope that she will lead them to Pearce; for reasons never adequately explained, he's driven to capture the elusive criminal and bring him to justice. Pearce stays in touch with Elsie through a series of handwritten notes, which are delivered in plain but neat white envelopes. Her latest instructions: Board a train from Paris to Venice, and along the way, throw off the authorities by seeking out and befriending a man with Pearce's height and build.

Here enters Frank Tupelo (Depp), a nervous math teacher from Wisconsin hoping to forget a personal tragedy. He reads a spy novel. He puffs away on an electronic cigarette. He fumbles for his words like a man on his first blind date. Elsie regards Frank calmly, all the while calculating every move. They arrive in Venice. She convinces him to accompany her to a hotel and stay in her luxury suite - and, of course, he'll have to sleep on the sofa. In the aftermath of an intimate dinner and a few drinks, they kiss on the balcony. The next morning, while Elsie is out, a group of strange men barge into the suite intent on killing Frank, believing he's Pearce. And so begins the thriller portion of the film, highlighted by awkward action sequences, a contrived romance, and curious sudden appearances by Rufus Sewell. I leave it to you to discover whether or not his character is red herring.

"The Tourist," a remake of the French film "Anthony Zimmer," has all the reliable crime thriller clichs, including exotic locations, mobsters, a train ride, a mystery woman, and an apparent case of mistaken identity. It even has Timothy Dalton, although his role doesn't require him to be James Bond once again; he plays Chief Inspector Jones, who finds Acheson incredibly irritating and seems to take great pleasure in telling him off at the end. But even with all this at hand, something is missing. For something meant to be thrilling, we never quite go beyond the image of Johnny Depp running barefoot across loosely tiled Venetian rooftops. The blood never really pumps. The adrenaline never really rushes. It's all so flat and tired and insipid - not at all what I expected from a movie like this.

There is, of course, an inevitable plot twist, one that surprised me by not being surprising. Perhaps that was shortsighted on my part. Considering everything that happens, considering what was said, considering what we're shown, could the film have ended any other way? Crime thrillers are constructed with the intention of misdirecting the audience before revealing the truth. What bothers me is that this movie makes no real effort to trick us; it leads to a conclusion that was obvious from the very start. With no good romantic subplot, with no decent action sequences, and with no engaging plot, what else is there? The more I think about "The Tourist," the more I return to its star, Angelina Jolie, whose beauty thoroughly overshadows everything else. That's not much of a compliment for the film itself, but it's the best I can do.

By now nearly everyone has at least heard of The Tourist, the thriller that unites huge stars Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie. It's one of the movies that's probably on everyone's must-see list based on star power alone. The problem is that The Tourist lacks anything that would make it a memorable or worthwhile experience, which is disappointing considering who's involved.

Federal agents have been following Elise (Jolie) for months as they wait for anything out of the routine to occur. The feds are after a man named Alexander Pierce, a man who Elise is known to be close with, that owes $744 million to the government. One day while tracking Elise, the unthinkable happens; something out of the ordinary finally occurs. What starts with a letter being delivered by a bike courier turns into a wild goose chase onto a train on its way to Venice. It's there that Elise chooses to sit next to a man named Frank (Depp), a math teacher who just so happens to be a tourist in Italy. As things progress, Elise constantly intervenes in Frank's plans and eventually draws him into her world where the federal agents begin to believe that Frank is Alexander Pierce since they have somehow never been able to get a clear look at his face. Frank is brought into the world of trickery and espionage, something that he's only read about in the spy novels he's so frequently caught reading. What began as nothing more than a stranger being picked out in a crowd slowly begins to culminate into a full fledged relationship that neither Frank or Elise can walk away from.

When it comes to Angelina Jolie, her role is a bit different than some of her other recent roles. She seems to always play that strong female role that is either more than capable of taking care of herself or is just as strong as some of the bigger men in whatever project she's a part of. While that isn't necessarily a bad thing, it gets a little tiresome and you crave to see an actor do something outside of their range. While Elise is said to be able to take care of herself in The Tourist, we really never see any proof of that. She takes a life preserver and smashes it into a guy's face who's hanging off of a boat she's driving at one point, but that's it. The rest of the time she's walking around in elegant gowns and trying to look as feminine as possible. That and not display any sort of emotion whatsoever. This isn't what I had in mind when I wanted to see Angelina Jolie do something different.

Johnny Depp doesn't have much room to talk either. While he's more than qualified to show emotional range or be incredibly eccentric at times, he seems to do nothing more than act like a watered down version of Jack Sparrow while doing the most idiotic and spontaneous things to put him in danger for a woman he's just met yet has become incredibly infatuated with. He does have a few one-liners that may get a chuckle or two, but they're delivered in such a flat tone that they'll probably be forgotten about once you leave the theater.

The biggest joke about the film is the ending. It is literally so cliche and so atrocious that it makes the entire film a complete waste of time. Once it's revealed who Alexander Pierce is, you're left wondering if this entire string of events was really necessary. Imagine taking the longest and most dangerous route to doing something simple like making toast and that's pretty much how The Tourist goes about doing things. I could just walk to the refrigerator and get jelly or butter or to the pantry for peanut butter, but instead I'm going to lock my desired condiment in a safe, lead someone on a wild scavenger hunt all over the city that'll put them in harm's way, and make the government think that they owe them a massive amount of money so they run into problems with the law at every turn. That'll be fun, right? It'll make that toast taste so much better in the end, but the bread turns out to be stale and you just gag whenever you try to eat it since you've grown sick of having to swallow it so often.

The Tourist is a stale thriller with flat performances from actors you'd expect a lot more from, but is still somewhat decent despite its flaws. I'm probably giving the film more credit than it deserves since I'm a fairly big fan of Johnny Depp and he was mildly enjoyable in small doses in this, but the film's ending pretty much destroys anything you may enjoy early on. It's just a shame since it had such potential to be a fun and entertaining thriller, but will probably still be mistaken for one because of the stellar cast alone.

the plot

The mysterious Alexander Pearce is a notorious British thief who is wanted by both the French and English authorities as well as the Shaw Mafia, an outfit he himself used to run with. Since not many even know what Pearce looks like, the French police along with Scotland Yard are tailing his girlfriend Elise Clifton-Ward, thinking that she will eventually lead them to him. The Shaw mafia has the same idea since they are unable to find Pearce as well.

One morning as Elise is having her breakfast at an outdoor bistro, she receives an envelope with a note inside from Pearce. It instructs her to find a decoy for himself so that those who after him would follow this distraction instead of discovering his true whereabouts. She then burns the letter, but the authorities were able to decipher the note with some sophisticated equipment and learn of this plot.

As the beautiful Elise makes her way to Venice, she spots an American tourist named Frank Tupelo and decides that he should be the patsy. Many chases involving both gangsters and police ensue leaving Frank confused and scared. Whenever Frank would get into major trouble, Elise would use her skillful maneuvers to rescue him before it's too late. Meanwhile Frank along this short way has discovered that he loves Elise only to deliberately put himself in danger to make sure she remains safe and alive.

the breakdown

I must be changing in my old age, as I once again liked a movie that I really didn't want to waste my time watching in the first place. To make matters more uniform, it is once again an Angelina Jolie project that makes a believer out of me, (one of the others being Salt). Both of these films were Angelina's film output for 2010, and they both have that running theme that Jolie is really some undercover super spy. It may seem silly, but I think it works for me. Angelina didn't really perform too many physical acrobats here like she had in Salt, actually if you compare the two, The Tourist comes off more like a romantic comedy more than a thriller, although that component is very present.

The comedic parts were mainly Johnny Depp lines. His character Frank, a school math teacher from Wisconsin, was very soft spoken and reserved. He must have had a lot of fun playing one of these clueless American tourist characters, as it fits well into his theory of how America is akin to stupid puppies or whatever stupid thing he said about us. Well, aside from Depp's insipid and misguided opinions, he was funny. His biggest laughs came from his attempt to better communicate with the Italian people by using the limited Spanish he knows, believing that he's speaking their language. The very evil Steven Berkoff plays the villainous Shaw effectively. Berkoff has an uncanny yet natural scary-type of evil criminalness about him that always gives his characters some weighty legitimacy. Ever since Beverly Hills Cop and the even more so Under a Cherry Moon, I've been truly afraid of his characters.

I liked The Tourist, despite that I planned on hating it, or even better ignoring it all together. I'm glad that my sneaky wife had moved this to the top of my Netflix queue. Oh it's for my own good I suppose. The Tourist will either keep you guessing the whole time, or you're going to be like me and think you have it figured out only to be proven wrong in the end. The film is rated PG-13 because Johnny Depp had to drop the f-bomb, which in my opinion didn't even make sense here. There was some violence, but nothing bloody or at all graphic. You should watch this with the family, as long as you turn up the volume so you can hear Johnny Depp's mumble-style of speech, and distract the younger ones when the f-bomb is dropped.

More thumbs down than I have for this one.  The mistakes, which seem so cliched, cynical Hollywood formula, will make your teeth hurt.  I love Johnny Depp, but this movie is terribly mis-cast.  All that would've been required to rescue this bomb would've been switching Depp's and Sewell's roles.  Consider Depp's work:  He requires parts that allow him to be outrageous, making him a poor choice for leading man.  He's wonderful, but he isn't subtle. Sewell, on the other hand, is capable of a wider range of totally believable, nuanced characterization, and could've given Frank such depth, glamour and humor.  And total believablity.  Besides, to paraphrase from the final scene, if you were going to spend millions for a new face, which one would you chose?

As for Jolie, in a part that recalls Audrey Hepburn in Charade or Grace Kelly in Rear Window, she is painfully campy and even ugly, bringing none of the Hepburn/Kelly easy charm that her role needed so badly.  I knew she was in trouble when she ate her morning croissant in gloves.  Really.

All supporting roles were played well, but need only have been phoned in, the casting was so predictable and safe, according to body type, and as Sewell has pointed out many times, facial bone structure.  The Russians looked Russian (variations of Khrushchev/Putin!), the British were Britsh (variations on James Bond -Timothy Dalton, and DS James Hathaway -Laurence Fox), the French were French and the Italians were beautifully Italian.

Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck's, The Tourist, is beautifully filmed and harkens back to the big productions of the golden era of Hollywood.  Johnny Depp's performance was sweetly charismatic in this remake, and Angelina Jolie is simply stunning as the glamorous female lead. Their onscreen chemistry was engaging and the entire cast showcased their talents in every scene.

My only real criticisms were perhaps how quickly Jolie's character, Elise, developed such a deep emotional attachment to Depp's character, Frank, when she was supposedly in love with Alexander, or the credibility of the cursory back story of Jolie's character.  Perhaps a few more scenes with Depp and Jolie may have solidified the emotional involvement between the two main characters, but both actors portrayed their characters well within the film. The talents of Paul Bettany, Steven Berkoff, Timothy Dalton, Raoul Bova, and Rufus Sewell also bear mentioning.  Their performances were equally entertaining as well, in both the dramatic and subtle comedic moments throughout the film.

A special mention to James Newton Howard and Gabriel Yared for the music.  Newton's music score truly captured the beauty and action throughout the film, and Yared's "Dance in F"  was exquisitely moving in its grace.  The film's soundtrack often was hauntingly beautiful and easily reflected a romantic intimacy that other movie scores simply lack.

The Tourist leads the audience into a world of intrigue, beauty, and glamorous elegance with beautiful locations and equally beautiful "movie stars" that many overlooked in favor of more mainstream films, which was unfortunate for this cinematic, charming escape.  Don't make the same mistake.  The Tourist is worthy of a look.

This Johnny Depp-Angelina Jolie disappointment is billed as a crime-action-mystery.  The most important mystery about the movie is what happened to the $100 million that the defrauded producers spent to make the thing.  It has brought in only $53 million world-wide to date and will be a financial disaster for the backers.  Jolie and Depp, stars of such stature that they are impervious to failure, will no doubt be just fine.
 The film has as inspiration the taught, complicated thrillers made so well by Alferd Hitchcock a half century ago and successfully imitated many times since.  Depp plays Frank, an American tourist in wicked Europe.  He becomes involved with mystery woman Jolie on a train and the plot twists and turns at the speed of a slow saunter.  The script, weak though it is, (and co-written by German director Von Donnersmark) is not the main problem.  We expect a degree of incoherency in an action flick, what we have to have is action.
 Depp is wonderful, as usual, in this role as an American naf caught up in events beyond his ken.  The supporting cast includes Paul Bethany, a terrific actor we remember with joy from Master and Commander, A Knights Tale and many other roles.  Even Timothy Dalton makes a small appearance.
  The problem is Angelia Jolie.  She is an actress that we appreciate most when she lets her freak flag fly.  In this one, she barely changes her expression.  I think that she is so monumentally photogenic that the director just did not know what to do with her.  She is paraded through the entire film from one set piece to another of her showing off expensive, tasteful designer couture, and to excellent advantage at that.  She is not so much acting as allowing herself to be exhibited.  Sometimes we ask beautiful, stoic models to appear in films after being taught to act.  Here it seems that an actress has been taught to be beautiful and stoic and to not act.  It is a bad bargain.
 Director Von Donnersmark has received an Oscar for best foreign film.  It seems that American style action films are not his forte.  It is only fair to note that the film has been nominated for three Golden Globe awards, which is not small change.  It is not explained however why the nominations are in the comedy category.  Is this some snarky, high brow sarcasm?

The clever, entertaining film reminded me of the great films of the 1960s and Angelina Jolie has all the lush beauty of Rita Hayworth and Ava Gardner.  Jonny Depp on the other hand remains the anti-hero, a bit ruffled and untidy, a bit sarcastic and yet innocent. The film could best be described with the word clever since it has an engaging and humorous script with many twists and turns that keeps the viewers attention trying to put the pieces together.

The film is a great puzzle that gradually unfolds and in this film it is very difficult for the viewer to get ahead of the story.  That certainly is nice for a change. The film uses an old Hitchcock technique where the female lead knows more than she tells and the male lead is somewhat of a bumbler with whom the audience can identify. But nothing is as it seems in this film.

"The Tourist" is very similar to some of the Hollywood escapist fair of the 1950's and early 1960's with the likes of Cary Grant, Audrey Hepburn and Grace Kelly. In several films during this era, Grant played an American in European exotic locales dealing with espionage in relatively light-hearted plots. The classic films of this ilk which come to mind are "To Catch a Thief", "Charade", even "Roman Holiday", taking place in Monte Carlo, Monaco, Paris, and Rome. In "The Tourist", Depp plays a Cary Grant-like character and Angelina Jolie has the long dark hair of Audrey Hepburn with the demureness of Grace Kelly. The action begins in Paris then moves to Venice.

The best thing about the film in some ways is the opening. The viewer is plopped right into the middle of things without any background or knowledge. A demure mystery woman (Jolie) arrives at a caf in Paris near the Champs-Elysees and orders something, which we learn is already being prepared. She's a regular. A mysterious note is given to her and provides detailed instructions concerning exact steps she's supposed to take right after leaving the caf. While she is reading the note, we learn she is being staked out by some kind of government officials. Part of the instruction says "...pick someone with my height and build and make them believe it is me..." She burns the note and makes her way to the central train terminal in Paris.

Part of the fun of the story is that we don't know who wrote the note, and part of the mystery-fantasy is a gradual revelation regarding who the unknown letter-writer is. (The voice-over for the note is Jolie, which is somewhat confusing at first.) On a train to Venice, she meets a clueless American tourist from Wisconsin, Frank, played by Johnny Depp. Depp (who doesn't exactly seem like a clueless tourist from Wisconsin) acts flattered that a woman who just walked out of Vogue Magazine would sit by him on the train. And so begins a rather fun, if somewhat improbable, misadventure. Depp appears to be someone "with my height and build". Two factions are on the trail on the unknown "letter-writer": Scotland Yard authorities who believe he has not paid back taxes on several billion British pounds, and an international mob run by an older baddie who would kill not only a man who cheats on his wife, but he'll kill his wife too, and all the members of both families. He would even kill the man's doctor, just for good measure. The mob boss lost billions to the mystery who was once a trusted part of his organization. Part of the plot is the tried-and-true "mistaken identity" device in which the authorities and the mob appear to be confusing the clueless tourist with the unseen letter-writer. Everyone is sure the man they want is Depp.

A fun fantasy which combines elements of romantic-comedy and international espionage. There are a couple obligatory chase scenes and even a romantic interlude or two, with the compulsory ballroom scene and casino. What makes it work are the fine performances by Depp and Jolie. The ending is pretty interesting, but there are aspects during the film which don't quite mesh with some of the scenes which have occurred previously. But if you're willing to suspend your disbelief and let your imagination run wild, "The Tourist" is a fun treat, sort of like a nice bow of vanilla ice cream. French vanilla of course on Viennese China.

This is a nice throwback to classic spy, mystery, thriller, romance films of the 1960s.  Don't expect any frenetic car chases with fast-cut editing here.  This is all about picture-perfect settings, elegant women, and subtle dialogue that creates a sophisticated look and feel within the wonderful European charm that is Venice.

Angelina Jolie is perfectly cast as a mysterious woman who oozes charm and seduction with every glance of her eye and subtle sway of her hips.  Scotland Yard and other European authorities are following her in hopes of finding a thief who has stolen a great deal of money.  Johnny Depp is a hapless tourist who through a chance meeting gets caught up in her web of activities and people tracking her.

The plot takes some small twists and turns that keep the viewer guessing a bit as to how things will turn out.  There is great cinematography amidst the wondrous canals of Venice, and no camera could love Jolie more than in this film.  Depp is drawn to her as a moth to the proverbial flame, and no man could blame him.

The movie falls short of a high level of excellence probably because of weaknesses in the script.  There were no glaring flaws exactly, but there were no clear strengths either beyond the basic concept.  However, the other film elements make up for this to create a fine escape with plenty of charm and eye candy from the settings and the personas of Jolie and Depp.  It's a nice tribute to an older style of European mystery-thriller and romantic-comedy filmmaking with a strong cast of modern actors in both the lead and supporting roles.

Based on the French film "Anthony Zimmer" this movie is about a thief who is trying to reignite a romance with a woman he left for two years.  With a new face, a new voice, and a new name, he lures the woman to Venice where he plans to reveal himself and explain his long absence.  The problem comes when the man he stole a fortune from learns he is in Venice and comes after him with a team of Russian thugs.  This movie puts its stars, Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp in unusual roles; Depp is the romantic lead, and Jolie does not throw a single punch.  Although I don't think they ever connect as a romantic couple on camera, they are fun to watch.  The mistaken identity angle is intriguing, the scenes of Venice are spectacular, and the music is great.  "The Tourist" isn't perfect.  As I said Depp and Jolie never really connect as a romantic pair, and the ending is a little flat.  In an effort to make her glamorous, they put so much makeup on Jolie that she looks like a department store mannequin.  They could have wiped most of it off and she would be more beautiful.  With that said, "The Tourist" is a beautifully photographed movie, with great cast of characters, and enough intrigue to keep the plot moving.  I suggest watching "The Tourist" and "Anthony Zimmer" together, and enjoying how the same story can be told in such different ways.

Depp and Jolie headline this tale of intertwined story lines, who is who, what is happening, and who's doing what?  Jolie plays a high-profile beauty who also happens to be the significant other of a criminal who is on the run.  In order to throw Interpol off of her trail in her effort to be reunited with "him", she selects an American school teacher (Depp) seemingly at random while on a train, and gathers him into this web of intrigue.  He is clearly in over his head...with her, not to mention everything else.

Jolie and Depp do top-notch jobs.  The story is engaging, the character development is good, and you are not likely to figure out what's really going on until the very end.

There are great backdrops, and I have to say that even though I don't care much for who-dunnits I like this film and I'm very happy that it's part of my collection.

To sum up, I'd say that this is a dark horse film that received very little attention when it was released, and is something of an underdog.  I suggest that you give it a look/another look and see what you thnk.

The Tourist(released Dec/10)stars,among others,Angelina Jolie as Elise Clifton-Ward,Johnny Depp as Frank Tupelo,Paul Bettany as Insp. John Acheson,Timothy Dalton as Chief Insp. Jones,Steven Berkoff as Reginald Shaw and others. I found this to be a very,very pleasant and enjoyable film to watch. The intrigue,the mystery,the plot twists and turns and the solid acting,all help propel this little number along.
The story finds Depp as the titled "Tourist".However,the movie starts out as the police in Paris,assisted by Scotland Yard in London,are busy following Jolie. Jolie is an ex Yard agent who they hadn't seen for a long time and who has been connected with one Alexander Pearce. Pearce it seems stole mega millions from a very nasty European mob boss,and not only are the police after him(thru Jolie),but the boss wants his bucks back pronto. At a cafe where Jolie sits a note is delivered to her via courier(from Pearce)and it tells her to board a train and head to Venice. Also it says to find and chat up another man on the train who has roughly the same build as him,so the police suspect that man is actually him.
The man Jolie chats up is our own Johnny Depp,a math teacher from Wisconsin. Depp of course becomes intrigued by this lovely enchantress sitting across from him. Jolie also feels an attraction but hides her feelings. In Venice she and Depp end up sharing a luxurious hotel suite there;Jolie sleeping in her own room,Depp on the couch. The next morning Jolie has left and is awoken by a servant bringing breakfast. When the servant leaves two thugs from the mob bosses`gang show up and Depp takes off across some rooftops to elude the men. He ends up being arrested. The policeman who interrogates him ,during the night,takes him out and delivers him into the hands of the mob boss,for a tidy payment. Jolie comes to the rescue and they both end up out in the Venetian harbour in a boat. Next morning Jolie delivers Depp to the airport and tells him to leave.
With Depp now gone,Jolie goes back to Scotland Yard and agrees to help her superiors in Pearce`s capture. She is wired and she attends a ball that night,as per the instructions of Pearce,through notes. Once there she is given another note by a man who rushes away. She follows him calling Pearce`s name. Who should suddenly appear,but Depp. They dance for a short time until she breaks off and leaves. The police,who are there en masse,take Depp into custody. They sequester Depp in the surveillance van,while Jolie is now inside a room,looking for a safe she was instructed to go to. In barges the mob boss with his men,who forces Jolie to tell him where the safe is. All this time police snipers on a nearby roof have had their guns trained on all of the baddies in the room,but the Yard cop in charge keeps delaying any firing;hoping for the appearance of the elusive Pearce. Jolie tries once to enter the safe code but fails and is given one more chance. Depp`s admonitions to the cops to jump into action to save Jole have fallen on deaf ears. Before the cops realize it,Depp has escaped the van,gone and entered the room from its balcony and now is inside confronting the boss,and pretending he is Pearce. As things look their worst the cop in charge`s boss comes in and orders the snipers to fire,which they do,taking down everyone but Depp and Jolie. As the two stand there Depp asks her how she now feels about him and this Pearce fellow. She replies she loves them both. Depp replies he may have a solution to the problem. Depp enters the safe code and opens it,something he would never have known if he wasn`t..... .The police arrive and Depp and Jolie are gone. They blow the closed safe to find a cheque made out in the amount that Pearce had stolen.
The film winds down as Depp and Jolie ply across the Venice harbour on a sailboat. Jolie makes the comment about all the money he spent on his facial reconstruction,and that was the best he could do? Depp asks ``you don`t like it``? Jolie says it will have to do.
Not only is the acting quite solid in this film,but it is all ably boosted by the cinematography and the beautiful background music. In fact at some parts,I saw some visual touches of Hitchcock, and could almost picture Cary Grant and Grace Kelly in these same roles. This movie definitely has touches of cinema from a by gone day,and it is rare to see that nowadays. The movie`s tension/intrigue starts out from the get go and I found it rarely let up until the two are sailing into the sunset. That nice twist ending was also a bonus.
Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 2:35:1 and is clear and crisp. Extras include commentary,outtakes,an alternate animated opening and two featurettes.
All in all a nicely done film with elements of mystery and intrigue coupled with a light sexual tension between the two leading characters. It`s visual and audio touches really enhance the entire look and feel. Highly recommended.

And this has nothing to do with the whole Jennifer Aniston/Brad Pitt thing; Hollywood has plenty of this kind of drama going on that it's nothing new. I admit I enjoyed her in Girl, Interrupted, she did a great job in that movie as well as the rest of the cast. In fact her earlier work is way better given that she did riskier roles compared to now. Just about every role she takes on is just very standard Hollywood, and when she was first getting big she was doing all kinds of unconventional roles. I recommend seeing the movie Gia where she plays a drug addicted model, it's a sad movie (based on a true story as well) but it's well made and acted. I also enjoy her in the Kung Fu Panda movies, although the major highlights of those movies come from the action and comedy. But in a way those movies go with her conventional roles of playing a tough as nails women like in Lara Croft or Wanted. So yes, she's done some good movies here and there. But for the most part, she's just meh. She rarely does a lot of emoting in movies, and giving a cold stare the whole time doesn't mean you're acting and giving any real depth. And sure I can see that she's an attractive woman, but not so much in recent years. She's started getting way too thin. And in terms of acting, her other half Brad Pitt is way better and has done some more interesting roles. This movie doesn't help with her looks either. There's the heavy makeup she's wearing and she looks silly with her attempt at a sexy walk. Really I'd say Girl, Interrupted was her last real daring role where she showed off some raw emotion and showed that she can act. But most of the things she does now are just her looking pretty, or trying to be a bad@$$. Now I still need to see some of her newer films. I haven't seen Changeling yet, but my main reason for wanting to see that is because it's directed by Clint Eastwood, who is really good at working with actors and getting them to give a decent performance.

As for Johnny Depp, I love the guy. He has a natural charm for sure. Yes in recent years he too has done more standard roles as well. But he at least still entertains me with these performances; Captain Jack Sparrow has become one of my favorite movie characters. And even in more standard films he seems to at least be putting in some effort, more than I can say for Jolie in most things. Not so much in this movie though. I'd say he was doing it for the paycheck. There's a quote by Jolie that she was just doing because she thought hey it'll be a quick shoot and she had nothing better to do. That's the secondary problem with this movie too. Neither are really putting effort in their performances. I can't really buy Depp as a simple math teacher; Depp has no business playing a normal person. His most normal performance was probably the original Nightmare on Elm Street, and that was a supernatural slasher film where he got sucked into a bed followed by a geyser of blood. The other would probably be What's Eating Gilbert Grape, but even in that he was part of dysfunctional family and surrounded by eccentrics. See both movies if you haven't, they're classics.

The primary problem with this movie is that it's predictable. Even from the trailer it was super obvious that Depp's character was going to be this international thief, otherwise it wouldn't be exciting enough. If you're star is Depp, of course he's going to be the suspect. Course this movie fails to be exciting as everything moves slowly. I'm guessing the $100 million budget was mainly because Jolie and Depp cost a lot of money. Course I'm sure Paul Bettany and Timothy Dalton weren't cheap either. I've seen more exciting, fast paced action films that didn't cost nearly this much. The 2006 actioner Shoot 'Em Up cost $39 million to make, that's more than half of what this movie cost. Look at the first Terminator movie, it only cost $6 million. Sure it's sequel cost $100 million, BUT that movie was fast paced and awesome! The 2003 Italian Job cost $60 million and was more exciting than this; sure it wasn't a fantastic movie but it was at least fun. This movie spends most of it's time wanting to show off the Venice. Sure Venice looks great, but this is supposed to be a thriller with some action and such. It doesn't deliver very well on that. The George Clooney film The American (released the same year) cost $20 million and had some stunning Italy landscapes, and it's pace was slow too, but it did it in a way that was able to still build tension and have some mystery to it. Now I can see the American dividing opinions, but I'll still stand by what I said when I think it has a more engaging plot. Since the twist of the Tourist is obvious, it just leaves you thinking of when they're finally going to reveal when Depp finally admits he's the prime suspect. If he and Jolie had chemistry and actually put effort into their performances I could ignore that because I'd least be entertained. But they don't, and it just gets really tedious. Going back to Charade, certain things were obvious, but again it had a great pace and Hepburn and Grant had excellent chemistry and used their charms. But Depp just looks bored. Say what you will about any of the Pirates sequels, but at least then you can tell he's having a good time in those movies. Also those movies used their budgets well to give us some mind blowing special effects and awesome action scenes (the whirlpool fight in World's End is EPIC!) and the rest of the cast I'm sure see he's having fun so they try to have fun. This movie though isn't fun though, another thing that Charade has above this movie. Most of the cast seems to be trying, but it really isn't enough if your leads can't wake up and do some acting.

That's really all I have to say. Hope I didn't ramble on too long. While this may not be super informative of the movie itself, I hope it at least entertained and I've managed to get people to watch the other movies I talked about. Seriously, any one of those movies is a lot more fun that this one.

There was a time, oh, from 50-60 years ago back to the beginning of film, when Hollywood regularly turned out smart, sophisticated, glamourous movies.  They were stylish and adult and entertaining.  Think "The Postman Always Rings Twice" or "Casablanca" or "The Story of Eve" or "The Seven Year Itch" and you will know the type of stylish, sophisticated glamour I'm talking about.  Yes, there have been some newer ones that were similar to the old ones..."The Thomas Crown Affair" for one, but they are far too rare.

"The Tourist" is utterly beautiful from the first frame to the last.  It's a pleasure to see Johnny Depp being so endearingly appealing, and Jolie at her absolute most stunningly gorgeous best.  Sadly, this movie won't appeal to most of today's audiences because there's no gore, no CGI, no breakneck action, no foul language, no sex; in short none at all of the things most audiences go to the movies for today.

The story needs no more talking about since so many reviewers have already outlined it, so, like I usually do, I will simply tell you why I like it.  It's a fun movie with humor, style, intelligence, elegance, romance, and lots of sophistication.

No, I don't put it into the same category as a Cary Grant or Bergman movie, and, no, I don't think in 50 or 60 years people will still be talking about it.  It's not a classic.  But it is well worth the time and money to see it, own it, and watch it several times.  It's a lot of fun.

This is a fun, under-appreciated movie. If you like "caper" films such as "Charade,"  "It Takes a Thief," or "How to Steal a Million," with stars Audrey Hepburn, Grace Kelly, Peter O'Toole, and Cary Grant; this is a film you'll probably enjoy. If you're hoping to see Angeline Jolie in a bodysuit, kicking butt with a flamboyant Jack Sparrow, you're going to be disappointed. Depp is known for tackling a wide range of roles, from Edward Scissorhands to Don Juan de Marco. In this film, he verges on being a dweeb, complete with a full set of pajamas--the kind men used to wear--with nary a chest hair in sight. Nevertheless, Depp's self-deprecating Frank Tupelo never seems ridiculous; rather he seems like a man caught up in an adventure he could only have imagined happening to someone else. Frank may not be suave and debonair, but he's resourceful and funny; traits that keep us, and Jolie's character, Elise, from writing him off too quickly. Although Jolie is convincingly enigmatic and glamorous, her performance is not as nuanced as that of Depp. We catch hints of emotional depths, but they remain hints. We never really understand what makes her tick. The rest of the film is solid: there is a good supporting cast, the costumes are spot-on, and the photography of Venice makes you want to catch the nearest plane for Italy. This movie was a very pleasant change from films that bombard you with special effects or scenes of graphic sex and/or violence in order to keep your attention. And if you can avoid typecasting the two leads based on previous roles, you may decide, as I did, that "The Tourist" is a gem that deserves to be discovered.

The Tourist is a delightful throw-back to the era of movies like "To Catch a Thief" and "The Pink Panther." We have both of those movies on DVD and watch them regularly with renewed pleasure each time. This movie offers the same level of fun and adventure with the added benefit of Johnny Depp's natural ability to be funny; I have no difficulty placing him in the same category as Cary Grant and Peter Sellers. It has action, beautiful scenery, a well done script, effective character portrayal by Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie, good acting in the supporting roles, and a variety of interesting special features.

We really enjoyed watching the film with one exception; the surround channels sound level sometimes masked the dialogue to the point we couldn't understand what was being said. There was, however, a simple solution; we activated the English subtitles and the problem was solved. (For the record all of the speakers are balanced within +/- 1 decibel)

Both my wife and I enjoyed the movie and had fun watching it. If you're a fan of the Alfred Hitchcock movies or the Pink Panther movies I think you'll have fun with this one too.

A movie like The Tourist is hard to be objective about when it comes with such star power, the critics widely trash it, and it goes from big screen to dvd within weeks. Even Ricky Gervais dog-piled not once, but twice to Johnny Depp's face during back to back Golden Globes ceremonies. I fully expected a total train wreck when I got around to watching it.

It's not a train wreck but it's not very good. In going for the narrow lightweight espionage/romance/travelogue genre, The Tourist comes across as nothing more than a pale imitation. Jolie can pull of old time movie star appeal but her cheesy British accent offsets any credibility her glamour points get. Furthermore, she doesn't so much act as model clothes and jewelry. Depp doesn't even try for suave and goes straight for schleppy teacher clich. I kept wishing he would visit a barber and transform, but he doesn't. In the milieu this movie strives to reproduce, even regular folk like Depp's character would be credited with a modicum of style and sophistication. In a movie that goes for style with substance, it was a poor omission. Furthermore, the heat between the two stars was tepid at best, as were the performances that wavered between mildly amused and comatose.

The Tourist is a gorgeous movie that surprised me more than I thought it would with touches of droll humor and a nostalgic tip of the hat to movies we are hard-pressed to find anymore. In the end, however, it seemed only able to recreate the lovely wrapping paper while leaving the box inside empty.

Angelina Jolie stars as Elise, an alluring and mysterious woman whose every move is being watched by Interpol. Knowing that, she boards a train for Venice and picks up an unsuspecting tourist (Johnny Depp) who quickly falls in love, is arrested, and has to run for his life.

I liked the beginning of this movie, thanks to Johnny Depp's' sweet portrayal of a mousey math teacher who naively speaks Spanish to Italians and can't believe his luck in meeting the glamorous and desirable Elise. Jolie seems less an actress than a model, posing with pouty lips and strutting around in designer clothes. She exhibits little emotion and is completely unconvincing as a Brit. The photography of Venice is so lovely, though, that it almost makes up for Angelina's miscasting. The movie starts off as a clever and fast-paced spy story but becomes muddled and even a bit boring later on; the twist-ending didn't seem to fit.

All in all, this is a pretty but silly movie full of plot holes that doesn't seem to know if it's a comedy, romance, or thriller.

Angelina gets the far better role here.  There are a couple of twists of course (one in the middle that I didn't see coming and the one at the end that was pretty easy to see ahead of time--but I won't ruin either of them here).  For me the most interesting character was Paul Bettany's Inspector who was WASPish in his desire to capture the film's "villain" and whose tone-on frustration in being repeatedly thwarted or overruled at every turn was a delight to watch.

The Oscar for "Best Movie Shot in Venice" goes to...THE TOURIST. The beautiful city of Venice, Italy was the best thing about this movie. The rest was...well...not really anything International Bad Guy vs Interpol different or edge-of-the-seat-whodunit startling. It was an OK 113 minute long piece of escapism. While the movie was entertaining, I didn't really care about the characters. Angelina Jolie standing there looking glamorous does nothing for me, and Johnny Depp, a gifted actor with long, unwashed hair, was wasted here. The real star was Venice. There were many beautiful views of this "Floating City" to marvel at. For that alone I rate it 3 and 1/2 stars.

Starring Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp, The Tourist is romantic thriller/comedy from 2010.  The central lead is Elise (Jolie), who is being pursued while on the hunt for her lover Alexander Pearce, a man who is on the run after reportedly stealing big dollars from a gangster.  Elise teams up with the unsuspecting Frank (Depp), forcing her pursuers to think he is Pearce in disguise, only to spark a thrilling chase through Venice involving both police and gangsters, both of whom are desperate to catch Pearce.  But will Elise and Frank survive, and will Pearce eventually show up?

In comparison to most modern thrillers, this is a slow-paced film, and not surprisingly it's been criticized by many for being devoid of action, and for lacking chemistry.  But what many perceive to be a weakness, I'd consider to be a strength.  The slow pace and apparent lifelessness seems to be a deliberate throwback to the older Hitchcock style thrillers, adding to the intrigue.  And while Jolie's persona comes across as cold and calculating (an effect maximized by excessive and immaculate makeup), it's her fidelity to Pearce that holds her back from Frank.  The respite from the usual sexual smut Hollywood is known for is welcome, and the amount of offensive material we're used to from contemporary thrillers is refreshingly absent for the most part, aside from a few instances of crude language.  It's true that the storyline lacks high octane action and special effects, but the romp through Venice is a visually pleasing one, and despite their cool interaction, the two protagonists keep the story moving and our curiosity aroused.

My only criticism would be concerning the surprising twist in the storyline at the very end of the film.  On the one hand it's a very well orchestrated surprise, but it does make the actions and motives of one of the characters earlier in the film rather implausible.  But at the end of the day, we shouldn't be taking this too seriously anyway, but just enjoy the ride.  If you're up for something slower and are happy to avoid some of the more offensive material that usually plagues Hollywood, why don't you hop on board this tourist boat and head to Venice? - GODLY GADFLY

Sophisticated in its beauty, lush with Venetian motif, and with such charming actors, to watch The Tourist is to become enchanted with the imagery and the romantic idea of Venice, more than with Venice itself.  The Tourist is to Venice what Roman Holiday is to Rome.

The movie's soundtrack is effective if not memorable, with a few nice surprises, including an appropriately subtle taste of Katie Melua in one scene which made me fall in love with her vocals all over again.

Apart from the imagery is a casually-paced plot with enough humor and suspense to sustain interest throughout the movie, but is it enough to make this a classic?  Will this stand the test of time?  Probably not.  Other than the sheer beauty, there is little here of lasting value.  All the more reason to appreciate the fun while it lasts.

The Tourist is a refreshing reminder of what great film-making is all about. I felt thoroughly captivated as soon as I started watching, as if a magic wand kept me glued to the screen. Jolie's presence was mesmerizing, projecting an uncanny combination of beauty, delicacy, fragility, elegance and femininity, in a way that is rarely seen on the screen (big or small), and combined with Depp's purity of presence and genuineness, there were some magical moments forming between them that are true cinematic gems.

The genius of the director is felt every step of the way, and if you prefer a genuine interaction between people (and some riveting action scenes) over a parade of special effects, you are in for a rare treat.

I fell in love with Venice and with Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie while watching this film. Wonderful escapism as the viewer is allowed to enter vicariously, the exclusive life-style of the ultra-wealthy (chic Jolie)and unexpected adventure of Everyman (unassuming Depp). For me the movie was a graceful integration of elements in To Catch A Thief and North By Northwest. The beautiful Venetian waterscape and architecture captured in the cinematography draws me into 'vacation mode', as if I'm a tourist there. Jolie plays a strong, in-control, and commanding personality that is at the same time softened by vulnerability, empathy, graciousness and poise. Now I want to emulate that character as well. Depp is amazing with the overlapping qualities of vulnerability and sensitivity of his own, as he navigates unforeseen circumstances with courage mingled within fear, as a tourist in a foreign country. I also loved the performances of Timothy Dalton -- patient, wise and likable, and Paul Bettany -- relentless, dogged, and frustrated to the end (compared to his brilliant acting as the 'Albino' in The Da Vinci Code). This movie should be stacked next to Cary Grant and Grace Kelly on your shelves, as it does mine. Masterful acting, smooth yet gripping script, and a classic feel which lacks the gruesome violence and lust so prevalent today.

I got interested in the reviews of this moview when I found many very low.  Most of these find it light or boring, a waste of superstar talent, etc.

Now, I'm not going to go through all the hundreds of negative reviews here and on IMDB, but the ones I have read I think are missing a critical point.

The chief characters in this film are living in a world where the people they are dealing with are corrupt up to their shifty eyeballs. Count the number of people on the take.  Or, take, the surveillance crew who zoom in on Elise to see if she is wearing underwear.  Or, notice the "bad guy" is a globe-trotting serial killer for the heck of it and no one seems to care much.  Or the fact that the police of Europe are all over trying to find the missing guy who stole (?) billions from the serial killer only so that the government can get its cut(taxes).

My take on this:

Here are two very intelligent people in the midst of this mess who are in love but have strong reasons to distrust each other (why not...nearly everyone else is betraying something or someone).  How can they regain each other's trust?

I happened to like the movie a lot because it had romantic music, showed colorful shots of Venice, had the two stars doing very well exactly what stars do in movies.  I like it even more now that I've realized that it does actually make a point.  It reminds me a lot of Casablanca, except in that film everyone has the integrity to hate the serial killers; but The Tourist has a better ending.

Note --

The missing person has not given word on his whereabouts to Elise for two years.  What is the first thing he says to her?

This Movie has an awesome cast which is really its strength point. Angeline Jolie and Johnny Depp in the lead, now who wouldn't want to see that ??

However, that being said the movie is clearly not a life changing one. If you watched the trailer already you should know you won't be hearing about The Tourist in the next  Academy Oscar Awards. However, the trailer is a bit deceiving while this movie has *some* action scenes involved the action is very light. So, this isn't a mindless action film full of chasing cars, swashbuckling heroes, and flying motorbikes. It has all the elements necessary to make a typical action film (Hero/Heroine, Government and secret agents, spying, High tech spying supplies, Evil Gangs, the Bad Guys, Murder etc, etc..) But for some reason the movie doesn't focus on these elements entirely thus the action is rather lacking, action fans you'll be disappointed.

What we get instead, is something else. If I can describe this film in one word it would "sweet". It has a sweet romance and some tender moments as a backstory. The Scenery is also a plus in here. You got a beautiful view once in a while of gorgeous European cities and being a travel freak I enjoyed that.

I heard people complain about the lack of nudity in this film. I personally didn't mind that, I'm in no way a prude but I'm not a fan of mindless sex scenes and I didn't find a legitimate reason for the Hero/Heroine to have sex till about the last 5 minutes of the film.

In the end I would give this a rent if for nothing else just to see Johnny Depp wandering in Italy trying to chase the woman he thinks he loves. Worth it ? I think so !

Any true film freak will tell you that "suspended reality" must be overcome for a vehicle to work. Here we have a woman who probably needs that three or four billion dollars her lover is supposed to have stolen to just keep her lips plumped. There isn't a single plot device here that hasn't been used with better outcome with much smaller budgets and lesser known actors.

Here's the thing; this should have been amazing.  First you have the cast.  Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp are two of the most bankable stars in Hollywood, and they are both talented (albeit overrated, but talented).  They ooze this charisma that makes their actorly flaws seem irrelevant at times.  Then you have the director.  Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck has one other feature length film under his belt; 2006's Oscar winning film `The Lives of Others'.  That film is amazing and his directing of it was flawless (he should have been nominated in the directing category).  Then you have the story; a solid mix of action and mystery and you have that beautiful setting; Venice.

None of it works.

The setting, while beautiful, feels cheap.  The actors, while talented, lack any real chemistry and don't evoke any emotions.  Angelina relies on her fading good looks to keep us engaged and Depp tries to play quirky again and misfires.  Sadly, Paul Bettany has been further reduced to stereotypical `obstacle' and does absolutely nothing with the role (quick, Russell Crowe, come to his rescue).  The direction is also just standard and uninspired.  It felt like almost every frame was ripped from a better Cary Grant/Alfred Hitchcock collaboration.  The story had all the elements for a nice capper and yet it felt underdeveloped and stale.

Angelina does nothing by pout her lips and smolder.  Depp does nothing but try to pull off ignorant.  Bettany does nothing by bark into the phone.

I liked the twist at the end even if it felt too predictable (and nonsensical at that), but the construction of the film as a whole was a total mess.  I'm just so upset over this.  I really wanted von Donnersmarck to follow up his brilliant debut with something a little more profound, or at least a little more epic (considering the genre and stars he chose).  Instead, `The Tourist' feels too tepid and too insipid to matter in the slightest.  I think the funniest thing about this movie is the fact that the Globes nominated it in the Comedy category.  It's not funny (at least not intentionally).  It didn't deserve to be nominated for anything, but the fact that they changed the whole genre to fit their need to nominate big name stars is just hilarious.

Skip this one.

Is this fine director being "type-cast"? Is he not allowed to stretch?Forget it! The attractive cast and beautiful scenery and a fun (though a bit contrived) plot kept me watching with interest. Film snobs may be disappointed, but you just can't fool kids, and we "kids" of all ages enjoyed it a lot.

A star studded cast provides a good performance for this action packed movie.  It's different to see Johnny Depp not acting as a pirate or other outsider character.  He plays somewhat of a normal guy.

I enjoyed The Tourist. It's not a life changing, Oscar worthy movie, but was something interesting to pass the time. I particularly enjoyed the ending. It was a nice surprise and I smiled and thought "that's cute." I have no idea what it's genre is though. I don't see it as a comedy (doesn't have a lot of laughs), not a drama, not a thriller (nothing thrilling about it), not adventure, not action (there's no action except a bland running away scene), romance? Could be, but there's really no romance between the two characters. They kiss probably 3 times and there's really no passion or intimacy.
As most have said, yes the scenery is gorgeous, stunning. The hotel Jolie and Depp stay in is beautiful. Seeing it all makes you wish you could be like this Alexander Pierce that everyone is after, with his stolen billions, so you can live in breathtaking Italy.
On to the flaws--the actors. Jolie is my favourtie modern actress. She's original, unique, different and I consider her one of the most beautiful women on earth--when she had on weight. In her last few movies for the past few years, she's unattractively skinny. She's not the take-your-breath-away beauty anymore, and it's because she's so damn skinny. Besides from her alarming and unsettling appearance, she's very stiff in this, and doesn't show much emotion. She swishes around in heavy makeup, long hair needing a cut, and dresses I actually consider ugly. There's a scene where she's very Audrey Hepburn with her dark sunglasses and pearls, and was the one outfit I liked, but they didn't show enough of her in that scene.
Non-emotion goes for Depp as well. I felt he played his part even worse than Jolie. What the hell is up with Depp in this movie?! HIM, not his character, seems slow, lethargic, bored, out of his element. He plays it with no force or vigor. He has a little interest in playing his character but just not enough. The face expressions are there, but the energy and movement aren't (Bad guys are running after him, and he's scared, his face shows it a bit, but there's nothing within projecting). His face is also bloated, old, and unattractive. Seeing him "normal", you see that he's short and petite in stature. I don't consider JD ugly, but never swooned over him or saw him as sexy. This movie solidifies that he does nothing for me. But I've always aloofly admired him and his movies; the fact he chose to play oddball characters, instead of the the action hero or the hot guy. Some reviewers have answered my question about what's wrong with Depp, and I agree with them that it's because he's only comfortable playing eccentric characters. For him to be normal, is to be a walking corpse, basically. Jolie has more range and can be different characters while still being "very Angelina" in each.
The supporting actors give much better performances. Bettany gets an A for giving his best to be the lead detective. The only other I consider lifeless like Jolie and Depp, is the bad guy Alexander stole from. Who they refer to as the "gangster." He's not intimidating at all and seems to be acting just to receive the paycheck.
All in all, watch this movie if you want to be transported to a beautiful mediterranean country called Italy, and would like to be entertained with a charming story about identity. Not for those that seek action, hate lighthearted, fluffy movies of the '50's and '60's, or require great acting from the actors.

I have a personal gauge for whether or not I enjoy a movie.  It depends on how quickly time seems to go by during the movie.  I've sat through what I thought were bad movies that seemed to go on forever.  For the good ones, time seems to fly by.  This movie falls into the latter category for me.  My wife picked it because it was set in Venice, Italy, and we will be traveling there in a couple of months.  When we started watching the movie, it was early evening and still light outside.  At the end, it was completely dark outside.  I looked around and couldn't believe it was so dark.  I was completely caught up in the movie.

If you're looking for a really deep plot, you probably will be disappointed.  Watch the movie with the idea of just having a good time and maybe you'll get lost in it as I did.  And I loved the ending!

I wanted him to be the math teacher and plastic surgery plot twists never worked for me-its just not believable.  And I wanted to hate the other guy-I wanted him to abandon her at the end and let the nice guy get the girl.  Also, Depp played the character as if he were the math teacher until the end.
