He plays innocents very well-that's why I think the character should have remained innocent-you wanted to believe in him.  AJ does show some depth and maturity here.  Some have said she was too expressionless, but one could also interpret that as minimalism.  Its better than over-acting, anyway.  There was too much focus on her looks but she was supposed to be a glamorous woman(or at least pretending to be-another problem-was she really believable as a govt agent?), so I'm not sure we should complain.  Sexually titillating, not a family film and a bit violent for my taste.  Not all bad, but a really disappointing ending, imho.

The script is silly, and I have not seen either Depp or Jolie look this bad in a movie before. Depp is a total frump and Jolie is frighteningly skinny and badly made up, with hair that looks like it needs washing and is probably not her own. The premise is hard to believe. It's not a thriller. It's a watered-down Hollywood confection. But, there is Venice and stereotyped Italian cops -- where is Giancarlo Giannini when you need him? As one reviewer pointed out, it starts slowly. It just doesn't really go anywhere.

Watching this movie gave me an epiphany about Johnny Depp's career, and that is his movies, especially those in the past decade, are about individuals who use planning and smarts to defeat those who have strength and numbers on their side.  His POTC movies are great examples of this as he outwits Captains Barbossa, Davy Jones, Norrington, Blackbeard and Cutler Beckett.  He does something similar in this movie, though his antagonists now are members of organized crime and Scotland Yard.  Though the trailers bill this movie as an action thriller, it is more of a mystery movie, with some comedy, some action, and some romance thrown in.  The dialog is very good, both between the two stars, and among the lesser cast members, especially given the fact that both Depp and Jolie are known more for their action movies than anything else.  The cast also features many other big names of past and present, such as Timothy Dalton, Rufus Sewell, and Paul Bettany.  Overall, a great movie, and one that will keep you guessing towards the very end.

With such a great cast, I was expecting a very exciting movie. The whole movie was seen by the preview shown on TV. It had one little plot twist at the end that just was not enough to make the movie worth watching.

I had to see this movie to answer the obvious question: If you put Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp in a movie together, do you get a really good movie or a really bad one? Evidently, you get a really bad one.

The whole thing is about A.J.'s thickly-lacquered face with its over-inflated lips gliding along - either when she's ambulating down the street or floating by in a motorboat. Let's just say she doesn't show a lot of range. She never - not once - changes her expression. The entire part could have been portrayed by a life mask made of epoxy, and fitted with slowly batting eye-shadowed lids.

If the woman were in some sense beautiful, this might all have worked, but she isn't beautiful in this movie. If the camera is framing her face, she looks artificial to other-worldly. If it zooms back a little, she looks skinny. If the camera zooms back a little more, she looks ridiculous, because she is so thin, her shoes look way too big. It's worth mentioning that A.J. shows no skin in this movie, probably because she is so emaciated that if she did, the only thing she would arouse would be concern.

Once again, it IS very important to analyze how A.J. looks in this thing, because that's the only thing this movie is about. (Some actresses come out with lines of cosmetics. A.J. should come out with a line of Alkyd enamel.)

No matter how good the actor, each has a default role he can do in his sleep and usually does. Johnny Depp has one - the one in this movie. That's all that need be said about him.

The villains are all Russian - except for the lead villain. He is actually British but LOOKS Russian, and (so it is explained) hangs out with Russians. So why isn't he Russian? Dunno. Have to guess the actor couldn't do the accent. Why are the others Russian? Don't know that one either. Russian villains are clich and so is the movie, so maybe they're just being decorous.

All the Russians are ugly; the American is hapless; all the male Brits but the villain who couldn't do the accent are dashing; Jolie, who was raised in Britain, is supposed to be beautiful, but misses the mark.

There have been some references to the predictable plot twist. I suppose you can call it a twist - albeit one that requires torque wrench. It was still predictable, but only because the movie was so bad that one could not possibly rule it out.

As others have noted, _The Tourist_ could have been done differently in the forties or fifties, with a script built around leads that had personality and chemistry. It would still have been a trifling affair, and a clich, but it would have been entertaining. This movie comes off like _Xanadu_'s attempt at a musical. The idea was there, the concept was straightforward, but the producing, directing, and acting skills to pull it off were lost in the intervening decades.

This attempt is simply incompetent.

I absolutely love this movie. It does remind me of the movies from the 50's with its beautiful rich hues and charming musical orchestrations. It has the simplicity of that era, and the visual brilliance of the technicolor of that period that seemed to make fabrics jump off the screen. I found myself hypnotized by the beauty of it all. Plus, there is the wonderful background--Venice, Italy.

Yes, I had read plenty of poor reviews for this movie, and I avoided it when it was in the theater because of the reviews. However, now I wish I had experienced this film on the big screen.

For me, it is a movie I will enjoy over and over again for its stunning visual effects. Angelina's beauty compliments this film (however, I must admit I was a bit uncomfortable with her tiny size). And, while I haven't watched a film with Johnny Depp in a while, I forgot how much I admired his screen presence. For some reviewers, there was no chemistry between Jolie and Depp. I, on the contrary, felt chemistry between them. For some reviewers, both actors played their roles insipidly, I enjoyed the subtleties of their performances.
I enjoyed this movie very much.  It's clean, minimal violence, and it's a nice love story.  The surprise ending was a plus.
I could review this movie in one word..... BORING!  Not even worth watching for Angelina Jolie.  My wife and I BOTH fell asleep.  It's about as exciting as watching the grass grow.

This movie is sort of a "no brainer" and has the feel of a 60's Cary Grant or Gregory Peck romp, but I suppose that is why I enjoyed it so much. Angelina Jolie pretty much cruises through the movie in high fashion and with beautiful make up. Johnny Depp on the other hand is a hoot as he subtly hams it up. The movie becomes predictable about 2/3 the way, but at that point it's "So what, I'm having fun watching this movie".
I found this movie very entertaining. Had some streaming problems but Amazon refunded my money because they felt the quality was not up to their standard.  Good Job Amazon!

I enjoyed the movie with all it's twists and turns.  Surprise ending.  Locales and people are pretty.  Johnny Depp, as always, makes his character very believeable throughout the whole movie.  I enjoyed the romantic interplay between him and Angelina Jolie.  Fun movie to watch.

The Tourist is an awful movie. It is worse than my previous worst, The Thomas Crown Affair with Pierce Brosnan. If you watch The Tourist after reading this review please do not come back to it to tell me I was right. Shame on you for watching what you were warned not to. It was, by far the biggest waste of time in my movie viewing history, please don't let that happen to you.

I found this movie very entertaining and thought Angelina and Johnny were a good match for their roles. I did go to the theater to see this movie when it was released and enjoyed it so much I purchased it. This is a movie I like to watch when there's nothing on TV I want to see. If your not one of those people who needs substance or are a movie critic with ridiculous expectations I think you too will enjoy this movie.

I loved this movie.  I did find Angelina a bit stiff, but still a pleasure to watch. Johnny Depp, as always, was brilliant.  The photography and locales were gorgeous and the entire film was a delightful surprise given the terrible reviews it received.  I was prepared to fast forward through the dreariest parts, but found I savored every moment and was sorry to see it end.  Bravo to the director and all involved.

"The Tourist" is funny and entertaining movie if one does not expect too much from it.  And it is difficult not to expect too much from a movie that features two great stars: Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp.  I loved the fact that the entire film was done in Italy, Venice to be exact.  Such location adds allure to this movie.  And in this film, Jolie gets to play glamorous woman, the kind that every man wants to please in every possible way.  As Depp states in one moment is she is the "least down to earth woman he has ever met in his entire life".  Jolie plays a character that dresses in latest fashion; is hypnotically beautiful and wears her jewelry and sunglasses with such grace and beauty that one cannot take their eyes off of her.

I think that even director of this movie got mesmerized by Angelina.  They even made Depp's character look like a baffoon at times.  She is cool and composed and Depp is nervous, speaks Spanish to Italians and looks like a helpless scardy cat.

If one does not assign too much value to this movie, it can atually be fun.
I really liked this movie. But ,I am a Depp and Jolie fan. Not necessarily together in the same movie tho'. Starts slow but ends great. Loved it !

I almost did not watch this movie because people put it down so much.  But I'm glad I did because it was entertaining and just seeing Angelina so glamorous was a treat.  I think people expected this movie to be action-packed, like most of her films and that Johnny Depp would be some kind of swash-buckling hero like he is in Pirates.  I don't like actors being pigeon-holed into roles and I'm glad they made this movie because it was clever and funny and must have been just a cool and not so demanding project for them.  The story is believable, they both acted well, the scenery was to die for.

People also made comments that there was no chemistry between them.  But if you look at the story, Depp's character was supposed to be an awkward, depressed math teacher and Jolie's a sophisticated woman of the world.  It was all part of the weave of the plot that this is so.  It all makes sense in the end.

I gave it 4 stars because there were some parts that I found holes in the story but otherwise, I don't regret watching this movie.

Who doesn't love Johnny Depp?  He is so cool in this movie.  About half way through the film I figured out what the end of the movie would be, but it was the ending that I wanted, so I was okay with it.  Angeline Jolie plays a Brit in the movie, and in all honesty, she did okay, but not fabulous with the language - she pulled it off, but I liked her as an actress, so I went with it.  All in all, it was a great story line and I enjoyed the movie. I plan to watch it again this week.  If I had any say-so, I would have added an extra bit of filmage to show how Johnny Depp's character ended up where he was on vacation - what he went through before getting there - but I would have added that at the very end of the film.  Oh well, I'm not a director or writer, so there you have it.

I had high hopes for this movie, particular given the acting talent involved.  I kept waiting for the pace to pick up, but it just kind of plods along.  Some great ideas but poor execution.  Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie manage to keep the viewers interest despite the pedestrian pacing.  I think if lesser actors were involved, this thing could have been unwatchable. Angelina Jolie in particular looks amazing in every scene.  I liked the movie just because of her and because it is set mostly in Venice. Could have been so much better.

It has subtle European sensibilities so your so your mainstream crowd isn't going to like this at all. Which is why people don't say they didn't like it and move on but actually get angry. Just look at all the one star posts. It's definitely enjoyable if you like the old Bond movies or movies like North by Northwest. Those are definitely the genre. Great dialogue, fun plot, good acting. Espionage with comedic undertones.

I will keep this short. Angelina's character was horrible. She barely spoke the entire movie. When she did, she was so monotone that it drove me and my friend's crazy. The storyline was bad and very predictable. Depp is definitely forgettable in this film as well. I never saw the original film but it doesn't matter. IT'S BAD!

I rented this video for .99 cents and I definitely would've payed full price to see it in theaters if I had known it was going to be this good. I've seen through a lot of plots by the time the first five minutes have passed in the movie, but this one truly kept me guessing until the end. Depp plays the part of the tourist perfectly, and the twists in this movie put me in a good mood for days. Definitely going to buy this.
Absolutely no chemistry between the leads, almost painful to watch them together. Horrible movie and the surprise twist was easy to figure out within the first few minutes.

Terrible, terrible, terrible. I rented this film for .99 and I want a refund!  This is the first time I've ever been motivated to write a review because a higher standard production is expected from all parties involved!

This is possibly one of the worst movies I have seen.  It is just horrible.  The whole move is tongue in cheek, but it seems no one informed the actors or directors.
Way too much talent to be wasted on this..

This film is sloooooooow. Angelina Jolie's double in the film was a manikin,Johnny Depp just not entertaining. Just a big show about nothing. The only good thing about it was I got an extra two hours rest.

I saw this movie on an airplane and have to admit I was pleasantly surprised.  Too many people let their opinion of a movie be colored by their opinion of an actor/actress.  A lot of people, for whatever reason, genuinely dislike Ms. Jolie (despite having never met her) and decide to pan everything she does.  So much so that I had actually expected to dislike this movie based on all the negative chatter from haters.  However, it is really a good, solid, smooth movie.  A little predictable?  Maybe, but most movies are.  Is there anyone here who didn't know Luke Skywalker would win and Darth Vader would lose?  I didn't think so.  If you watch this movie with an open mind, I think you will like it.  If go into it focused on how much you dislike Ms. Jolie (or Mr. Depp), why bother?  As for the people who say Ms. Jolie "can't act" they are just plain wrong.  YOU may get distracted by how she looks and think that all she does is look good, but the woman is an exceptionally subtle actress.  Mr. Depp also gave a solid performance.  This is a sly, understated movie and I think a lot of people just missed it.

This is an excellent action/adventure movie and I was very happy to see two of
my favorite actors on the same movie. Johnny Depp delivers a great job of a confused
and out of place tourist. Angelina Jolie as an unknown agent is wonderful.
As usual I found that the DVD version was more than I had hoped for.
This is an awesome movie.  Don't even begin to listen to the critics.  Makes you want to go to Venice!!  Johnny Depp is funny and Angelina is amazingly gorgeous.

Who but Johnny Depp could maintain two characters throughout nearly an entire movie? I love the chemistry between these two. It's easy to enjoy with the backdrop of this elegant, smart film! Please more movies like this and less gore and reality nonsense!!! A definite "watch it more than once" movie.

If you need "instant gratification" in your entertainment, look elsewhere...
Otherwise, prepare to revel in the slow seduction and intrigue this movie will provide.

Not a typical "romance" story, however the forces sexual tension and passion could only be held back by the presence of the immense dignity of the characters and respect they have for each other. Neither is this an action movie.... the wheels of my mind were constantly turning and I found my heart racing at times. I appreciate that it isn't so simple-minded that it can be categorized into a specific genre, I prefer have diversity in film.

A beautifully filmed movie, perfect for those who appreciate clever stories with subtle, yet powerful acting.

Just like the old days. ;)

~ lechicklet 28/F

This film was so bad that I thought it had to be a Disney one.  Depp seems to have sold his soul to Disney, so why not?  Well it's a Sony film not Disney, but it was just as bad as fifty other films Disney has made.

The Tourist is certainly beautiful on the eyes.  Beautiful location, beautiful architecture, an extremely beautiful Jolie.  How all women would wish they could slide around the planet looking like that.  As for the storyline, not so bad.  You're kept in the dark right to the end, which I suppose is what will keep you watching.  As for Jolie & Depp, I felt uncomfortable watching them, to be honest.  I found their performances quite watery.  Usually a firm fan of Depp, he didn't look comfortable in this role, oftentimes coming across as quite wimpish, something akin to a wet dish rag. His character didn't come to life for me until right at the end.  The movie would have been better served with two 'not so A-List' actors.  The producers were obviously wanting a guarantee of sales.
Jolie and Depp could only pull off such a romantic plus comedy with a flair of who is the bad guy. The ending is not what you would expect.

OMG what a horrible movie. I'm a Johnny Depp fan so much so that i tried watching a movie with Angelina Jolie. It was a bad decision. The plot was ridiculous (even for a blockbuster), and the performances were totally unconvincing. I think the best part of the movie is the way it was shot and the beautiful setting. Aside from that, it's just not worth the time.

Based on a 2005 French Film titled ANTHONY ZIMMER.  The Golden Globes nominated it for Best Picture, Best Actress and Best Actor contrary to people arguing whether it was a comedy or drama.  There's some sparkling dialogue moments here and there but you have to get that this isn't a typical Hollywood picture to get the film.  It's really similar to old 50s films like CHARADE and the like with a few interesting twists and lush scenery.  The homage to old style films arguably has more to do with why it got GG nominations.  Rufus Sewell was underused.  I expected to rank this movie lower so it was a pleasant surprise. STORY/PLOTTING: B to B plus; CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: B; SETTING: B plus; MY GRADE: B to B plus; WHEN WATCHED: early May 2011.

Intrigue, romance and so much more.

Refreshing to watch something with glamour and subtle innuendo, rather than crass language and blatant nudity.

The scenery is beautiful, the dialog is flirtatious, Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie take us on a chase that's a surprise from beginning to end!

...to the point where I could have written the storyline.

Everything about this movie was predictable and cliched, almost from the beginning to the end. I just watched this for the first time 2 days ago and afterward I asked myself, "Really?". Was that all? Maybe it's a harsh judgment, but that is what I thought about the Tourist. It's a one hit wonder, meaning I won't be watching it again.

It's almost as forgettable as Salt, and that's saying something.

So why give it 3 stars?

Well, 2 stars on this site would mean that I "didn't like" the movie. It's not that I didn't like the movie; it's just that I wish I didn't catch on to it as quick as nails. The other guy who might have been Pearce never even crossed my mind as a consideration for BEING Pearce. Not even a fleeting thought of, "Could that be him? Nah. Bleh.".

3 stars means the director made a good try of it...and failed.

At least for me he did.

Having gone initially to the theatre to see THE TOURIST primarily to view the chemistry and performances of Depp and Jolie, we had found the movie predictable and drag-y.  Catching it at home on a second viewing, we discovered its fun, found the chemistry we had been too impatient to concentrate upon and discovered we had a really good time with the film.  We still found the tour of Venice a bit 1960-I SPY-ish, and the direction uneven.  However the stars did shine more brightly than on first viewing and the surrounding players  made it an enjoyable evening.  Sometimes we need to see a film a second time to discover its virtues for the first time.  .Blue Ray in the home, a really good pizza and a nice Chianti:  Now that's a good investment!

What an odd movie. It seemed to me like it just couldn't decide what genre to be - comedy, heist, or action-thriller. It seemed to be setting us up for the second at the beginning, then would occasionally lapse into one of the other two, but then never really committed. Depp seemed to be clowning it up at times, ala Pirates of the Caribbean, but nothing previously prepared me for that, so it always felt out of context. Angelina is gorgeous, and is supposed to be a little other-wordly in this, but she was so much so that I couldn't really figure her part out. And the two really didn't seem to have much chemistry at all, which surprised me. That would have been OK if it was a heist type movie that kept you guessing until the end, but I had guessed the end pretty early on, and so had my husband. So it just didn't work overall.

The only thing that saved it somewhat is that Depp and Jolie are both so gorgeous, even in a bad movie. And the Paris/Venice settings were also gorgeous, so there was plenty to look at:-)

Who is the actor who's only appearance is in the last 2 minutes of the film?  He looks like Maurice Benard (Sonny Corinthos from General Hospital) Help - it's driving me crazy! I can't find his name/character anywhere in the extended credits.

this is a pretty good movie. johnny depp and anjelina jolie are awesome in thismovie. i do have to say that thismovieis not spetacular like everybody says.but it is a really good movie worth watching and buying. if you have not seen this movie then i recommend you do

A throwback to films like ARABESQUE, CHARADE and other 60's "romantic suspense" films, THE TOURIST is a stylish, exotic caper.
Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie bring their marketable star power to good effect as our star-crossed lovers.  Sumptuously filmed in Venice and Paris, THE TOURIST languishes along with chase scenes and moderate action sequences until its clever finale.
An entertaining but not classic film.  Supporting players Timothy Dalton, Paul Bettany and Stephen Dorff add some pizzazz and of course Depp and Jolie are charming.  You could certainly do worse.
Item purchased met my expectations

This movie was well done and acted. It had me trying to figure out why the female lead paid for all of the male lead's hotel and other items, which was explained very near the end. I like movies where you can't guess the ending.
I really enjoyed this movie. The acting was outstanding! It reminded me of the movies of the past, in that the ending was a surprise. I recommend this movie!

Two great actors, but a very weak and predictable plot. Some of the boat chase scenes were obviously blue screened with background added later. Hey, if the hair does not move, you cannot be racing through Venice's canals. Come on!

Totally love Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie this movie brought two of my favorites together in a very well written and wonderfully  filmed movie.  The story line is great, location in Venice simply breath taking and beautiful as the leading lady.  Scotland Yard, french, gangsters and russian mobsters.  All the good stuff in the old classic movies I grew up watching.  Usually used to seeing Angelina in action films so it was a different pace seeing her as such a lady without punching someone in the face.  Johnny playing an ordinary american on holiday was absolutely sweet and endearing, I wanted to be in the seat next to him.  Of course the end of the film, yes was great.  A fitting end to an uncertain adventure.  Reminding me a little of The Saint with Val Kilmer and Elizabeth Shue, another fun move with  a lot of the same characters and great ending.

I didn't go into this movie looking for academy award performances and certainly didn't find them. As for a plot that makes sense, I didn't find that either. I've seen plots on SyFy that made better sense. However, I did come away from the experience with a smile on my face, and that's all that matters.

Ms Jolie did an awesome job of looking awesome. She excels at that. In this movie, she reminded me an awful lot of Vanessa Ferlito, or maybe it's the other way around. In any case, it seems she posed more than moved throughout much of the movie. That was okay. She played a good foil for Captain Jack... I mean Johnny Depp. As the schlubby tourist math teacher, he did a pretty decent job. On occasion, however, a bit of his Jack Sparrow slur would leak through in his speech. It wasn't distractive or anything, just a bit of bias I had.

With all that out of the way, the movie started rather slow, with all the foreign detectives tailing her, especially with the annoying subtitles. This is a good time to mention that you must have your picture ratio set properly on the TV or the subtitles will be cut off. In our case, it was just plain annoying to have to keep switching from English to subtitles, back and forth. Luckily, it wasn't all the time, but enough to slow things down, especially during the first half of the movie. One of the big plot holes is where Timothy Dalton tells Paul Bettany to close down the case in the first quarter of the film, which Bettany doesn't, then tells him again at the end of the film. Will he the second time? We will never know, but that is just a small example of the things that do not add up in the plot. There are many more.

It all doesn't matter. The European scenery is fantastic, the Angelina scenery is fantastic, and I guess for the girls, the Johnny scenery is also fantastic. The interplay between the main characters is decent if not a bit underdone. The interplay between the secondary characters, as in the law-enforcement people, is more for comedic effect than really serious. It was a shock to see Paul Bettany playing a good guy for a change. I keep thinking of him in that role in DaVinci code. The final plot twist could be a shocker to some people if you don't look too deep into things, or it could be totally implausible to others.

Not a bad rental. Recommended.

This film was promoted all wrong. Had it been billed as a comedy, I think reviews would be much better. Very dreamy and romantic with some action thrown in. Glad I finally ignored reviews and gave it a chance! Jolie and especially Depp were wonderful. There was one twist in the plot which I found too far-fetched for comfort, but this is a remake, so I'm assuming this falls in with the original storyline. And it gave me a great laugh.

The pace was glacial, on purpose, I know, and the action minimal.  It didn't make it as a cerebral thriller, action thriller or love story.  It just menadered all around them.  Jolie looked lovley and Depp seemed flat.  I was bummed.  I enjoyed their cover on Entertainment Weekly more.

A film of astonishing banality, "The Tourist" (2010) stumbles from one lifeless sequence to the next. Angelina Jolie strikes a pose while Johnny Depp looks hopelessly befuddled in this predictable and boring attempt at Hitchcockian suspense. One of the worst big-budget movies ever made - a jaw-dropping embarrassment for all concerned.
I fell asleep after i lost interest.  I usually try to finish a  bad movie just to find out what happens but these two actors were bogus together.

This movie showcased Angelina's beauty and mysterious charm, that is by far, her greatest asset.  Johnny did well portraying a simple average Math teacher, who was taken away by Angelina from the very beginning.  This movie had a light, but elegant mix of suspense, star power, intrigue, adventure, comedy and a great ending.  I know it was not meant to blow us away, but that was not a bad thing.  I am a big fan of foreign films which are usually very similar to a film like this.  A good film is not always a measure of how MUCH is put into it, but sometimes about how LITTLE is put into it.  It kind of like a great meal consisting of small portions versus an average meal consisting of large portions.  Which would you prefer?  Americans tend to prefer the latter.  This film was not overdone, yet, is was very good in it's genre, which is not too common in American cinema. It was sad to read the bad reviews because I enjoyed the shoot locations and all of the actors; this movie really was well casted.

It had potential but as I watched it more and more disenchantment set-in for the following reasons:
(1.) Jolie's acting consisted of showcasing her physical attractiveness and little else.
(2.) Depp's acting consisted of his always entertaining, but tiresome for this shallow story, quirky mannerisms.
(3.) Too heavy dependence on Venetian setting and extravagance, etc. to compensate for a disjointed storyline and minimalistic acting.
(4.) Storyline was a disjointed ripoff of segments of similar past movies e.g. accountant steals money from bad guy boss; Russian mafia; hot girlfriend implicitly involved; exotic locations including the usual gondolas; speeding boats and always just-missing gunshots; deceptive getaways that were not very believable; inept cops of various nationalities; extremely unlikely guessing games such as Depp's changed appearance from the original thief now turned into small town math teacher - really not even close to being a logically solvable solution to the story's guessing games.
(5.) Had potential but forgettable. They should have taken a year or two to write a more intelligent and creative story.

P.S. Those associated with this movie might rescue their consciences by donating some of their ill-gotten profits to some worthwhile cause such as, just to pick one,  girl's education in Afghanistan.

This film isn't going to be for everybody. I can see how someone who was not interested in the extreme eye candy here (in my case that would be Venice... and Depp...) could say it was a little bit slow. It takes time to "smell the roses" not only of Venice but the glamorous and elegant, which I have to say even though I don't like Jolie she pulls off extremely well in this film. There is incredible cinemetography here, an interesting plot that will leave you guessing, and some good action sequences. I rented the movie for the first viewing and after seeing it plan to buy it for repeated viewings. I can't give it five stars though because there are some questions left in my mind in the plot, loose ends that never get tied up, like how Alexander knows Elise will go so far down the train and choose to sit with him instead of any of the guys ahead of him. But all in all, things like that are minor and forgettable compared to the unforgettable scenery, outstanding costume design, charm of Depp, and the fact that this film is dripping with elegance. I felt opulent joining them on this journey.

Average at best. Nice cinematography alone does not do the trick. The few action scenes felt like slow motion. If you like to watch Jolie or Depp, this may be something for you. Otherwise, do not waste your time.
I loved this movie The DVD came in great timing. It was in Great condistion. Yes I will buy from this Seller again

The Tourist is the 2010 English-language debut from director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, who previously directed the highly acclaimed German film The Lives of Others. Sporting a cast lead by two of the biggest movie stars in the world, the movie opened to mostly negative reviews and mixed audience reaction. After seeing this movie twice, I think the negativity is somewhat misguided. It's not a great movie, simply a fun piece of mindless entertainment that never takes itself too seriously. Apparently, this movie's light-heartedness and mindlessness is lost on audiences who think every film is meant to be taken seriously unless there's an explosion every few minutes. Angelina Jolie plays Elise Clifton-Ward, a beautiful woman being followed by the police in Paris as they attempt to apprehend Alexander Pearce, her former lover. Pearce stole two billion dollars from a gangster named Reginald Shaw (Steven Berkoff) and is wanted by Shaw for this transgression and by the authorities for tax evasion. Elise receives a letter from Alexander that directs her to board a train to Venice and find someone of his height and build to mislead the police. Obliging him, she boards the train and meets Frank (Johnny Depp), an everyman schoolteacher. While the police quickly realize that Frank is not Pearce, mistaken identity puts Shaw on Frank's trail. The movie co-stars Paul Bettany as the lead investigator of the case Inspector John Acheson and former James Bond star Timothy Dalton as Chief Inspector Jones. While I too have found flaws, there are several things The Tourist does right. Shot in Venice, the locale is beautiful and cinematographer John Seale gives the film a beautiful, elegant look. Of course, discussing this movie and elegance it would be a sin not to mention Jolie who all but seethes elegance the moment she enters the frame. Jolie's performance as Elise has been accused of being "stiff," which is a criticism I highly disagree with. This is not a role that requires her to conjure up great emotional depth. Elise is a glamorous, mysterious woman and Jolie captures that perfectly. While Jolie looks like the glamorous movie star she is, Depp is rugged enough to be convincing as the empathetic everyman and he basically steals every scene he's in. Depp is a quirky, inventive actor who can usually find an interesting character attribute to toy with. As Frank, he's playing a wholly average man who is immediately in awe of Elise and the situation she's dragged him into. Depp is clearly having fun with this role and the way he tackles it makes it immediately fun to watch. His everyman shtick is not without a unique charm that only Depp could provide. His one-word reaction to seeing Jolie at the hotel for example is priceless. Criticism has also been aimed at the perceived lack of chemistry between Depp and Jolie. How is it possible that two of Hollywood's biggest movie stars could not have chemistry together? Well, I found that they DO but it's not Bogart/Bacall-type chemistry but more of a stilted, awkward one. This is entirely appropriate as Frank is in awe of the fact that a woman like Elise would even talk to him. Towards the end of the film, the two transcend that initial awkwardness and develop a convincing romantic dynamic. It's a cute chemistry that Depp and Jolie share, just not one for the history books. The Tourist was marketed as an action-comedy and has elements of both, but is more of a throwback to films that give plot a backseat to beautiful movie stars and a beautiful locale. Von Donnersmarck is an acclaimed director whose last film was a pretty heavy drama and it seems obvious that this film was an excuse to go to a beautiful place and have fun. It's obvious that the actors involved had the same intentions. This is not a movie that's meant to be taken seriously and if you watch this movie under the impression that it's Oscar-bait, then a lot of elements would seem poorly executed. If it's not apparent from Depp's performance alone that this is just a fun, light-hearted romp then you need to watch more movies. Even the action/chase/Depp-in-peril sequences are fun and light-hearted, without being too heavy on the suspense. With all of that in mind, even as the light-hearted romp it is, there are both mild criticisms and serious flaws present in The Tourist. For a film with beautiful cinematography and production design, the score by James Newton Howard, while not bad by any means, is rather typical of a European espionage film. The music just lingers listlessly in the background, rarely making itself noticeable. The biggest flaw here is the final twist; a twist so forced and contrived that it insults the film that came before it and fails on no less than two levels. The first is that it is completely devoid of logic, it makes no sense, and it betrays nearly all the characterization that came before it. If you watch the film aware of the twist, you realize that a particular character is either incredibly stupid, forgetful, or just blissfully unaware of the twist that directly involves him. Few movies have an ending that seem more tacked on than this one. Even worse, the script is co-written by Christopher McQuarrie, the Oscar-winning scribe behind The Usual Suspects. The twist at the end is already unoriginal and something that we've seen many times before but the fact that McQuarrie, in a shameless act of self-plagiarism, was responsible for writing it simply adds insult to injury. This is obviously a major problem, but beyond that I have little to gripe about. The Tourist is light entertainment that aspires to be nothing more than that. I think everyone involved succeeded at making the film they intended to make and, for what it's worth, they did a commendable job. If not for the twist that insults both the film and the people watching it, it could be much better. There is nothing particularly memorable or fresh about this movie, but it is much more breezy and enjoyable than the critics would have you believe. If you're in a mood where you feel the film Knight & Day will be too taxing on your mental energy, The Tourist is exactly the breezy entertainment you're looking for. GRADE: B-

THE TOURIST has many flaws, not the least of which is the fact that it doesn't seem to be able to make up its mind whether it is a suspense thriller, a romantic comedy, or a travelogue. Bouncing around from Paris to Scotland Yard and eventually to serenissima Venice the visuals (thanks to cinematographer John Seale's ability to capture the flavors of Venice so beautifully) steal the show. The story written by none other than Julian Fellowes ('Gosford Park', 'Separate Lies',  'Young Victoria', 'Vanity Fair', 'From Time to Time') with director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, Christopher McQuarrie, and Jérme Salle (whose 2005 French thriller 'Anthony Zimmer' spawned this American version) is quirky by entertaining, and the musical score by James Newton Howard adds distinction to the film.

Elise Clifton-Ward (Angelina Jolie, dressed to the nines and looking like a mannequin) is on a mission: she is being closely followed on secret video by Scotland Yard Inspector John Acheson (Paul Bettany) and Chief Inspector Jones (Timothy Dalton) who expect her to meet up with one Alexander Pearce and gain back the money stolen from crime lord Reginald Shaw (Steven Berkoff). She eludes capture and boards a train to Venice where her instructions from Pearce suggest that she meet a man who looks like Pearce.  Interpol is engaged and the Italian police - led by Sergente Cerato (the extraordinarily handsome Alessio Boni) et al - pickup the chase for Scotland yard.  On the train Elise meets American spy-fiction fan and math teacher Frank Tupelo (Johnny Depp) and manipulates his emotions and attention to the point that Frank follows Elise to Venice - and the mystery thickens. Amid interesting characters are 'The Englishman' (Rufus Sewell) and Conte Filippo Gaggia (the ultimate Italian leading man Raoul Bova, remembered for his important role in 'Under the Tuscan Sun') who add to the suspense and incidents of mistaken identity.  To say anything further would rob the viewer of what little suspense the script contains.

The very fine cast seems to be sleepwalking through much of the story, but they are still so terrific to watch that they make the film a fine evening's entertainment.  Probably this film is better on DVD than it was one the big screen in theaters: the story seems more intimate and the relationships more credible.  Grady Harp, March 11

"The Tourist" opens with Angelina's character under surveillance in Paris. A mysterious man, Alexander Pearce, is wanted by numerous agencies and criminals for having stolen billions of dollars and disappeared. Angelina is his girlfriend, and everyone assumes she is the best way to find him again. She receives a hand-delivered note from Mr. Pearce telling her to get on the next train to Venice, and to befriend and travel with a man that looks like Pearce--to distract and deceive the authorities, we assume.

She does as she is told, picking out Depp's character, who is a math teacher and widower from Wisconsin. Soon, he is caught up in the intrigue, since many now believe he is Pearce. This is further confirmed by Angelina's budding love for him and her impetuous decision to give him a kiss in full view of those keeping her under surveillance. Yes, eventually, we get a few chase scenes, a few twists, and some humorous bits of dialogue. But this movie plods along on poor writing, with every gangster being cut from cardboard, every intelligence officer lacking intelligence, and even the hints at chemistry between Depp and Jolie stifled by a plot that is surprisingly thin for such a grand international thriller.

"The Tourist" was made with the best of intentions, there is no denying that. Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck's ode to Alfred Hitchcock's To Catch a Thief (The Centennial Collection) is breezy, charming entertainment. The story here may seem pat on the surface, and upon it's initial viewing the ending may come out of left field for some. But be sure to pay attention because everything does add up. By design you will not be able to fully appreciate Elise (Angelina Jolie) and Frank's (Johnny Depp) romantic relationship, which is a major part of the film, the first go around. It's in that narrative hurdle that many will be turned off by the film or worse, dismiss it all together once it ends, but like I said, a second viewing will certainly clear things up and even make it much more enjoyable. The chemistry between Jolie and Depp is, much like the film, light as a feather. This is something that can also be counted as a detractor but I thought it worked quite well. Films of this style need a breezy air about them and Jolie and Depp easily bring that to the table. In the end "The Tourist" is misunderstood and underrated. I think many contemporary film goers just aren't familiar with 1950s European romantic mysteries like "To Catch a Thief" making it nearly impossible for them to properly gage "The Tourist." If you are aware of this style "The Tourist" will be a light, fun diversion. It's nothing special but it's certainly nice to see that they tried.

A few disclaimers:
1. SPOILER ALERT--this review includes spoilers, especially the most important one that the plot revolves around.
2. I don't care for action movies, especially the ones that are strictly for the sake of blowing things up to sell tickets, etc.--mindless action movies with little plot, in other words. So the lack of that, or sex, or profanity, is not why I didn't like this film. It's fine if a well-done, quality film has contextual action in it, though.
3. I adore Johnny Depp and think he's the greatest actor around today, or ever, actually. He was born to act. I loved him in this movie--yes, I'm also somewhat biased when it comes to him, I admit--but I'm totally objective when it comes to his movies. There are a few I don't like at all, some that are good or just OK, and some I dearly love. But this movie isn't one of those, unfortunately:
I give it a 5/10. When I first heard Johnny was going to do this, I had two immediate reactions: 1) YAY, he's finally doing a movie with AJ--who I firmly believe is his female counterpart in the looks department. And 2) This movie doesn't seem like his usual style, and it seems kinda....beneath him.
So I was curious to see if it would stand out above the usual formula chase 'em/plot twists and turns/who's really the criminal and who's not suspense thriller genre flicks, of which To Catch a Thief seems to be the standard by which all the subsequent ones go by, and of which some are awful and some--like North By Northwest--are great.
This was lacking in atmosphere, continuity, dialogue, plot...I could go on. I was disappointed after seeing this movie--the plot was contrived and skewed, like the confusing train scene, for one example---DID she know or just suspect (or neither) that he was Alexander, or had they had that set up from before so that it was only the audience that was fooled? Overview:

This PG-13, 103 minute movie can be considered to be a Drama/Action Film with a sprinkling of comedy. The film centers mainly on Elise Clifton-Ward (Angelina Jolie). She is being watched and trailed  in Paris by French police working with Scotland Yard. However, a certain mobster also has a keen interest in her, because her male companion, an investment banker, has stolen a vast sum of money from him.

Plot:

Elise receives a mysterious letter from the very illusive Alexander Pearce, a former lover, with explicit directions to board a train to Venice, Italy. The curious thing about this is that no-one knows exactly what Mr. Pearce looks like. The plan is for Elise to find a stooge or decoy on the train, that everyone will take for Mr. Pearce. That's where Frank Tupelo (Johnny Depp) comes into the picture.

Venice:

This city was a wonderful selection for this movie. It stretches across 117 small islands in the marshy Venetian Lagoon along the Adriatic Sea in northeast Italy. Because of its unique characteristics, it yields itself to some very interesting in city boat chases.

Nowadays where movies are laced with tons of CG to make the impossible appear to be able to happen, it is quite refreshing to see a film where the onus is instead placed upon the actors themselves as well as the atmosphere of the locations. Some may say that this film is `boring' because of this, but I think that it allows the film to come across in a more sincere manner, and it feels like a breath of fresh air.

I get what director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck (The Lives of Others) is trying to achieve with this stylishly ludicrous 2010 romantic thriller. It's an homage to the glamorous movies that Stanley Donen directed back in the 1960's like Charade (Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn) and Arabesque (Gregory Peck and Sophia Loren) which featured two attractive film stars at the peak of their allure in games of deception usually ensnared in an even bigger web of espionage. Perhaps because of his musical comedy background (Singin' in the Rain), Donen had a light touch that worked perfectly to set the tone of those classics. On the other hand, von Donnersmarck in only his second directorial effort displays a far more literal style that is anything but frothy, and sadly seems at odds with the souffl touch this film badly needs to make it true escapist fare. He co-wrote the twisty, preposterous screenplay with two masters of the mystery genre, Christopher McQuarrie (The Usual Suspects) and Julian Fellowes (Gosford Park), and the film boasts the requisite star power with Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie. But something just doesn't feel right about the whole venture, and it may be a case of too many cooks in the kitchen waiting for their paychecks. Looking every inch the glamorous movie star, Jolie plays a mystery woman named Elise Ward who is being trailed by the French police working in cahoots with Scotland Yard. She receives a note from her former lover Alexander Pearce at a sidewalk caf instructing her to take a train to Venice, find a stranger that looks just like him, and convince the police that the stranger is Pearce. Elise finds Pearce's doppelganger-to-be in Frank Tupelo, a meek math teacher from Wisconsin, and the chase begins in earnest as Elise reveals to Frank that Pearce stole two billion dollars from a surly gangster and is wanted for tax evasion by the police. The film feels like a series of heavily orchestrated set pieces meant to dazzle but only succeed in sputtering into incredulity, especially a sluggish boat chase in Venice's Grand Canal, the water of which looks ridiculously pristine. The ending is basically on par with Pam finding Bobby in the shower at the end of Season 8 of Dallas and just as convincing. Dressed to the nines by Colleen Atwood and immaculately made up, Jolie looks stunning and acts as best she can like she is the star of one of Donen's movies, but Depp is strangely at sea in his Cary Grant/Jimmy Stewart everyman role. Without a layer of makeup and his standard set of eccentricities, the actor flounders in an oddly blank-faced manner that makes Elise's attraction to Frank all the more puzzling despite his blind acts of puppy-dog devotion. A strong supporting cast has been assembled but given little to do beyond looking exasperated or confused - Paul Bettany as an inspector obsessed with capturing Pearce, Timothy Dalton as the chief inspector, Steven Berkoff as the merciless gangster, and Rufus Sewell as the mysterious stranger the police try to trail. Venice looks as inviting as it did in David Lean's Summertime through John Seale's lens, especially the glorious Hotel Danieli where Frank and Elise steal a kiss that sets the police after him. It's too bad that the chemistry between the two stars playing them is so wan.

The look of the film, with plenty of Venice and Paris in the mix, is gorgeous - but Angelina Jolie is used almost as a setting in herself with so many long pauses for the audience to presumably savor the look of her. And the plot line, swooping music and script itself is stale and recycled.

Or those awkward lines, pauses on Angelina, and god-awful Russian gangsters are something else: absolutely hilarious. THE TOURIST, whether or not it aimed to be so funny, succeeds in being a top-notch parody of traditional thrillers. By the end, the bizarre twists and humor had reached such a peak that I was practically crying from laughing! Lighthearted and unexpected, THE TOURIST is hilariously awkward in the best way possible.

The Tourist sets out to be a romantic mystery in the footsteps of Alfred Hitchcock.  Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp may not be 21st century versions of Grace Kelly and Cary Grant but a Jolie comes close being an ice princess. She is so impeccably dressed and poised that she deflects all emotion.

Spoilers below.

For me Angelina Jolie's character needed more of a past. We need to know to know that she has crossed the line from a Scotland Yard agent to compromising herself with Alexander Pierce.  Perhaps Inspector Acheson (Paul Bettany) should pick her up for questioning early in the film instead of Jolie walking into a police office to report after a year of saying nothing.

Scotland Yard is motivated to capture Pierce because he owes the British government several million in taxes.  Since Pierce has stolen a huge amount a money from a crime boss one wonders where the taxes are coming from.  Pierce's character does not seem to warrant so much attention from the police. Maybe if he was also selling government secrets or had something that both the British government and the crime boss wanted there would be a more plausible reason for all the international fuss about capturing Pierce.

There also is the problem that Jolie is not supposed to recognize Depp's Frank Tupelo as Pierce yet be drawn to him at the same time.  The lack of recognition places some distance between the characters at the conclusion when Jolie and Depp go off together it all seems abrupt. Unfortunately, Rufus Sewell doesn't get enough screen time as the phony Pierce to convince us that he might be the man everyone is searching for.

End Spoilers

The Tourist has good performances by Paul Bettany, Jolie and Depp, but their performances were more on the average side than exceptional.  Steven Berkoff made a demented villain but I had some trouble taking him seriously.  For me, the backdrop of Paris and Venice gave the film its appeal.  Having Johnny Depp running across the rooftops of Venice in pajamas made the chase far more interesting.  The Tourist is interesting to watch, especially if you have an affection of Paris or Venice, but the story could have been thought out.

The director's first film was an academy award winning, deep tense emotionally fraught political drama.  Maybe critics were upset when the director changed tacks this time around and decided to make a more accessible entertainment, in the Hitchcockian vein. Regardless of the bad reviews critics gave this movie, I think the director succeeds admirably at his objective.  I was entertained throughout, Depp and Jolie are solid, and the cinematography is spellbinding.
